fileDesc.extent: Approx. 6 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 1 1-bit group-IV TIFF page image.

availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

titleStmt.title: In eruditissimos sacrorum bibliorum polyglottorum compilatores poema.
titleStmt.author: Oldisworth, Giles, 1619-1678.

notesStmt.note: Imperfect: tightly bound, with loss of print.
Reproduction of original in the Bodleian Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2008-02 SPi GlobalKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2008-03 Mona LogarboText and markup reviewed and edited

div.head: IN ERVDITISSIMOS SACRORUM BIBLIORUM POLYGLOTTORUM COMPILATORES: Poema.
div.l: ESto; res anguſta domi virtutibus obſtet;
Sed facilè emergit, quae veneranda, cohors:
Ʋſque extrema novum ſcabies hoc occupet aevum;
Ferrea at haec aet as aurea prela dedit:
Sit turbata ſuis erroribus Inſula; purâ
Intereà ſacri fontis abundat aquâ:
Vileſcat, meritò ſibi ſpreta, Brittannia; nullam
Spreta, tamen, famam non ſuper are potest:
Nempe, quod externus nullus Rex praeſtitit, illud
Anglus, privatus, pauper, egenus agit!
Ergo, pace tuâ verſu quos dicere non eſt,
Sunt numeri, Lector, delitiaeque meae:
Hiſpida ſuccinctum fecerunt nomina metrum,
Et, tu quae credas barbara, docta ſonant:
Vos humilis celebrem Thorndick, Fearn, Rieves, Baker, Walton,
Selden, Smith, Vicars, Graves, Fuller, Uſſer, Whillock,
Stern, Drak, Stokes, Pocock, Sanderſon, Shelden, & Hammond.
AEternùm, Veſtro nomine, clarus ero!
〈…〉 & veſtra volumina testor
Omnibus 〈◊〉 qua 〈◊◊〉

Complutenſia ſunt bona, e •
Hiſpanica praeſunt,
His meliora potens biblia Gallus habet;
Quae tria, ſint veſtris collata, volumina fient
Chartis, & foliis mox leviora ſuis:
Scilicet, haec iſtis praecellunt biblia, penè
Humanis quanto Biblia ſacra libris.
Horum, ſeu, methodum, linguamve, typumve requiram,
Horum me methodus, lingua, typuſque juvant:
Quot partes numerem, numerem miracula; cunctis
Mirac'liſque venus, neſcio qualis, inest!
Ʋnum, & idem folium diverſa, eademque reponit,
Ʋnnm, & idem folium fit numerare labor!
Quaeque ſuam & retinet ſortitam Verſio claſſem,
Et (quid non potuit lucidus ordo?) decet!
Singula dicta, ſibi variè repetita, recurrunt,
Singula ſed variè, ſic repetita, placent!
Non, niſi ſeptiplici linguâ vox ulla refertur,
Nec, niſi ſit decies lecta, legenda ſemel!
Talem quis, demum, leget hanc? nemo, (autumo) nemo,
Vix tu, (quòd credam) candide, Lector eris:
Digna quidem lectu, ſed conſpicienda, revolves,
Te Spectatorem poſtulat hicce liber!
Linguas, qui potis eſt, legat has; ſin perlegat unquam,
Judice me, ritu Clericus ille legit:
Has tamen ille leget, lectas intelliget ille,
Veſtris qui monitis erudiendus erit:
Foedera ſacra (Patres in publica commoda nati!)
Et datis, & capere haec foedera poſſe datis;
Teſtamenta Dei, Vobis Scriptoribus, extant;
Extant antiquis, jam, renovata modis!
Ambo nil mutata, ambo mutata videntur;
Prodit utrumque Vetus, prodit utrumque Novum!
Retrò ſeſe geſtit utrumque; retroque reflectens
Primaevâ gaudet ſimplicitate frui!
En, ſacra ſemper erat toto pretioſior auro
Pagina; bis tanti, Veſtrâ operâ illa valet!
Eximias adeò ſecum fert undique limas
Linea quaeque ſuas, litera quaeque •• as!
Nec miror; Veſtros, nam, caſtigatus adungues,
Omne ſuum punctum Textus ubique tulit!
Hinc, vos praeclaros tantum non Pagina ſacra
(Sit licet à vobis ipſa colenda!) colit!
Vos, in Scripturis, (liceat modò dicere) fama
Magdelenae inſtar, non peritura manet:
Laudem, in Evangelijs, conſert Eccleſia; laudem,
Hei mihi, quòd meritam reddere nulla queat:
Quiſquis retribuet tanto quae Codice digna,
Hôc majora nequit ferre, minora neget:
Salva tamen res eſt: hic enim complectitur in ſe

Quod in ſunt 〈◊〉 praemia dig •••
••• or,
Hunc ſemul inſpiciam, Chriſti ſunt omnia plena:
Meſſiam narrant ſingula, junct a probant!
Mons Domini, hic, paſſim montes ſuperimminet omnes,
Gentium ubique patent Canaan, atque Sion!
Hymnos enumerant Muſae, cantantque Sibyllae,
Et liceat ſacro, nunc, Helicone frui!
In ſanctam linguam tranſivit lingua profana,
Nec purum labium ſolus Hebraeus amat!
Credita Judaeis referunt myſteria Gentes,
Fallere quas Eber, ſi velit ipſe, nequit:
Mentiri ignorant tot linguae: accepimus illas
Quae nil, ſi cupiant diſſimulare, ſciunt:
Divinum quoties concinnant undique Verbum,
Huic, cui non credunt, credere poſſe docent!
Eja, agitote, Patres: juvet haec encomia vobis
(Atque refellente haec nemine!) danda fore;
Gentiles calami minimè nos credere poſſe,
Nos Veſtri calami credere poſſe docent!
Antiquas linguis alias his addite; famam,
Par eſt, ut Veſtram plurima lingua canat:
Omen ineſt; nec vana loquor; nec ſit leve, ſumma
Quod, quae profertis, Biblia pondus habent:
Quid quòd hoc Auguſtum, totos monument a per orbes
Vobis, poſt cineres, conciliabit opus?
Imò quale Deum deceat, praegrande volumen
Vivis exhibuit, non monumenta, Deum!
Sanctus (ſi qua ſides) haud nunc, velut antè, bilinguis
Spiritus exiſtit, ſed Polyglottus adeſt!
Docta viris doctis quae Biblia vertis honori,
Sint (Polyglotte) Tui gloria, Noſtra ſalus.

closer.signed: AEGIDIUS OLDISWORTH, Anglus, A.M. Burtonii ſuper Montem Rector.
